body:
We all know that for a while, search engines (most famously Google) have started changing their algorithm to promote the content they want you to see, which makes it extremely hard to find what you're looking for. Even websites with their own search engines, like social media and news sites, are doing this.

However, it seems that I'm literally the only shithead on Earth who is affected by this. Everyone else can still immediately find what they're looking for, even if it's buried on some obscure site or post that never shows up in any search results. When I spend 2 hours and come back with 1-2 things, everyone else can still find 731208560478534718232524 things per second. It's like they have some kind of telepathic ability to just pluck the links to what they want out of thin air.

One example is posting pictures. I created +foxes, and have trouble finding enough content because I can only search google images, reddit, and imgur. However, many posters could easily find multiple pics or videos from a variety of buried social media posts and extremely-little-known websites. They do this from tons of different sources, all the time.

Another example is news stories. Everyone except me can find about 100 cool news stories (or politicians' comments) per hour the nanosecond they come out, just by "looking" for them. Well I also look for them, and only ever find the very top, trending stories, that everyone has already seen. There is no way to find anything else other than pure luck, so I don't know what kind of magic you all are using.

So, search engines are basically useless now. So how does everyone still find everything online, and why does everyone always try to sidestep that question when I ask them (as if I'm not supposed to know for some reason)?

title: How do you all still find everything on the internet even though search engines suck now?

body:
Its not just you, we're all fucked...

Finding cool old pictures for MY guild are ALSO hard to find...  add the fact that fucking getty and alamy have fucking put their 'ownership' all over it makes it almost impossible.

How the FUCK do they have the right to just take other people's pictures and claim ownership??!  WHY ARE THERE ALWAYS PEOPLE THAT RUIN EVERYTHING?!

Anyway...  i just adjust my search terms every couple of pages.  Eventually, you'll end up with someone else's page that has photos...  you can use them, till you run out.  Then start again.

As far as news?  Seriously...  if you're IQ is below 100, you are literally getting brainwashed...

author.bio_html: god, what a bad run this site was.

body:
I always use a lot of different search terms to get to what I want, that is if I cant find anything with just one. sometimes i get hits, sometimes i don't. I may even switch browsers to see if it yields different results. oh, and I search in my native language and english because they always give me different results :)

if I'm searching for pictures though, like snails or foxes, I usually go to forums such as petsnails or 4chan. I've never really used imgur to find pictures, only to upload them, mostly because I've found that it's just the same over and over again, which you're having trouble with.

and I can't really say anything about news (sorry) as I dont really follow them; it just makes me depressed

I find that it really boils down to how you use your search engine in terms of vocabulary. I hope I'm of any help?

That's what I do too, but no one else ever has to resort to this.

>  if you're IQ is below 100

It's probably in the negatives. But I still know not to trust the news. What I meant by news was just announcements or stories themselves, although this search thing goes for commentary type stuff too.

body:
Another thing you can do, that i've done... is have two separate browsers.  One for everything, like shitposting and checking mail, etc.

And another without ANY LOGIN INFO WHATSOEVER.  No cookies, no third party cookies, no location, no camera, etc.  Block fucking everything you can so the browser is not recognizable.  

THEN, do your searches...  also, you should probably use Brave, or even Opera.  AND DON'T USE DUCKDUCKGO.  That shit is garbage disguised and marketed as some sort of censorship free shit.

When I spend 2 hours and come back with 1-2 things, everyone else can still find 731208560478534718232524 things per second. It's like they have some kind of telepathic ability to just pluck the links to what they want out of thin air.

One example is posting pictures. I created +foxes, and have trouble finding enough content because I can only search google images, reddit, and imgur. However, many posters could easily find multiple pics or videos from a variety of buried social media posts and extremely-little-known websites. They do this from tons of different sources, all the time.

Another example is news stories. Everyone except me can find about 100 cool news stories (or politicians' comments) per hour the nanosecond they come out, just by "looking" for them. Well I also look for them, and only ever find the very top, trending stories, that everyone has already seen. There is no way to find anything else other than pure luck, so I don't know what kind of magic you all are using.

So, search engines are basically useless now. So how does everyone still find everything online, and why does everyone always try to sidestep that question when I ask them (as if I'm not supposed to know for some reason)?

body:
Yeah, some of them could tone it down a little, but just restricted to quality stuff they still find *WAY* more in an hour than I ever could in a year. And not all of them just copy & paste everything. Lukginzis for example almost all his posts are good quality, and there are like 100 of them per hour. Meanwhile I can't even find 10 crappy ones in 2 hours.

And the posters in +foxes knew of every fox pic and video on the whole internet, and every place to find them, and how to find new ones the second they come into existence. Me? I don't know a single fucking thing aside from a few things others have told me.

Every time I ask these people how they do it, they always sidestep the question and avoid actually answering. Even people who know me and like me. It's like everyone is hiding things from me.

body:
no one always gets the results they're searching for, I rarely get them; but then again, if I cant find it in english, I'll use my other language to find something, this tends to give me more (sometimes less) results. I guess people know different sources that may give them their results, and they search for/in that place. 

I mainly only use petsnails and 4chan for pictures so I cant really say anything for other sources, however I just stumble across them. petsnails is a forum for people with pet snails, I have pet snails, therefore when I was searching for things relating to them, i.e proper care, species, diseases etc, I found the forum. and I can imagine theres forums for all kinds of pets, like foxes- people keep foxes as pets. maybe searching for a fox forum might help somewhat? for 4chan (I use like I use ruqqus), /an/ is where I get my animal and land pictures, today i discovered a thread for fox pictures, some of which I havent seen before, and I saved some of them.

so really, you tend to just stumble across things, wether that be from someone telling you about it, or you finding it searching for something. I doubt people always find the source, it's usually that someone stumbles across the source and then spreads the source that then reach your ears

parent.body:
Search engines never give me many different results, no matter how I change the terms. Everyone else just seems to have an index of all the pictures and videos of something in existence, seemingly sortable by how cool or mundane it is too.

> I usually go to forums such as petsnails or 4chan. I've never really used imgur to find pictures, only to upload them, mostly because I've found that it's just the same over and over again, which you're having trouble with.

Yeah, but then how do you find all these places in the first place, when search engines never show them? I know of a few places now that other users have told me, but that's still only as good as those few sources, not how they discover them. And it also doesn't explain how people just find every post on generic social media like twitter or something.

post.body:
We all know that for a while, search engines (most famously Google) have started changing their algorithm to promote the content they want you to see, which makes it extremely hard to find what you're looking for. Even websites with their own search engines, like social media and news sites, are doing this.

However, it seems that I'm literally the only shithead on Earth who is affected by this. Everyone else can still immediately find what they're looking for, even if it's buried on some obscure site or post that never shows up in any search results. When I spend 2 hours and come back with 1-2 things, everyone else can still find 731208560478534718232524 things per second. It's like they have some kind of telepathic ability to just pluck the links to what they want out of thin air.

One example is posting pictures. I created +foxes, and have trouble finding enough content because I can only search google images, reddit, and imgur. However, many posters could easily find multiple pics or videos from a variety of buried social media posts and extremely-little-known websites. They do this from tons of different sources, all the time.

Another example is news stories. Everyone except me can find about 100 cool news stories (or politicians' comments) per hour the nanosecond they come out, just by "looking" for them. Well I also look for them, and only ever find the very top, trending stories, that everyone has already seen. There is no way to find anything else other than pure luck, so I don't know what kind of magic you all are using.

So, search engines are basically useless now. So how does everyone still find everything online, and why does everyone always try to sidestep that question when I ask them (as if I'm not supposed to know for some reason)?

parent.body:
Yeah, some of them could tone it down a little, but just restricted to quality stuff they still find *WAY* more in an hour than I ever could in a year. And not all of them just copy & paste everything. Lukginzis for example almost all his posts are good quality, and there are like 100 of them per hour. Meanwhile I can't even find 10 crappy ones in 2 hours.

And the posters in +foxes knew of every fox pic and video on the whole internet, and every place to find them, and how to find new ones the second they come into existence. Me? I don't know a single fucking thing aside from a few things others have told me.

Every time I ask these people how they do it, they always sidestep the question and avoid actually answering. Even people who know me and like me. It's like everyone is hiding things from me.

There is no way to find anything else other than pure luck, so I don't know what kind of magic you all are using.

So, search engines are basically useless now. So how does everyone still find everything online, and why does everyone always try to sidestep that question when I ask them (as if I'm not supposed to know for some reason)?
post.title: How do you all still find everything on the internet even though search engines suck now?

body:
bro you're so fast at responding

what am I supposed to be looking at in the guilds you linked me? these people posting there are not everyone, and they may be actively looking at a site for news, kind of like how you would read the news paper every morning commuting to work in 1960 for what's new. I'm pretty sure you have also stumbled across new sources.

and no one knows "literally every picture and video on the internet," people know sources. some of which may not show up *any more*, but used to. people know pictures and videos by chance, like how I know of a video of a praying mantis eating a woman's nipple by chance. it's not something I searched for (because I'm scarred) or really wanted to see, but I did. 

please just understand that it really is just a game of chance, this internet stuff. you're not always going to get something you're searching for. however you're not always *not* going to find something either.

parent.body:
Another thing you can do, that i've done... is have two separate browsers.  One for everything, like shitposting and checking mail, etc.

And another without ANY LOGIN INFO WHATSOEVER.  No cookies, no third party cookies, no location, no camera, etc.  Block fucking everything you can so the browser is not recognizable.  

THEN, do your searches...  also, you should probably use Brave, or even Opera.  AND DON'T USE DUCKDUCKGO.  That shit is garbage disguised and marketed as some sort of censorship free shit.

post.body:
We all know that for a while, search engines (most famously Google) have started changing their algorithm to promote the content they want you to see, which makes it extremely hard to find what you're looking for. Even websites with their own search engines, like social media and news sites, are doing this.

However, it seems that I'm literally the only shithead on Earth who is affected by this. Everyone else can still immediately find what they're looking for, even if it's buried on some obscure site or post that never shows up in any search results. When I spend 2 hours and come back with 1-2 things, everyone else can still find 731208560478534718232524 things per second. It's like they have some kind of telepathic ability to just pluck the links to what they want out of thin air.

One example is posting pictures. I created +foxes, and have trouble finding enough content because I can only search google images, reddit, and imgur. However, many posters could easily find multiple pics or videos from a variety of buried social media posts and extremely-little-known websites. They do this from tons of different sources, all the time.

Another example is news stories. Everyone except me can find about 100 cool news stories (or politicians' comments) per hour the nanosecond they come out, just by "looking" for them. Well I also look for them, and only ever find the very top, trending stories, that everyone has already seen. There is no way to find anything else other than pure luck, so I don't know what kind of magic you all are using.

So, search engines are basically useless now. So how does everyone still find everything online, and why does everyone always try to sidestep that question when I ask them (as if I'm not supposed to know for some reason)?

body: For news Google has ridiculous bias in which outlets it shows you. However, there's a trick to it: When running a normal search and hopping to the "News" tab, there are some options in the "Tools" menu that let you filter and sort stories by date rather than "relevance". All of a sudden you get to see smaller sites reporting on stories which the rest of the media refuse to cover, such as vote fraud at the moment. The normal algo will never show you it at all.
body_html: For news Google has ridiculous bias in which outlets it shows you. However, there's a trick to it: When running a normal search and hopping to the "News" tab, there are some options in the "Tools" menu that let you filter and sort stories by date rather than "relevance". All of a sudden you get to see smaller sites reporting on stories which the rest of the media refuse to cover, such as vote fraud at the moment. The normal algo will never show you it at all.

body: I've actually been using DDG as my main search engine for about a year, it does well even for more techincal things (which I had trouble with at the start of my use).  I was able to switch my parent's engine about 6 months ago with no complaints thus far.  I'd also have to use google for directions but since DDG started using apple maps, that is no longer the case.  I'm actually really satisfied with DDG.  I think one of the hardest things about switching is language.  "I'll google it" was a hard thing to recondition myself.

body: The thing about DDG is that it essentially ctrl+f's the search results and tries to give you something which contains as many of the words you typed as possible, without actually trying to make sense of the search inquiry the way google or other engines do. It does technically prevent censorship in that sense, but it also makes it very difficult to search for something you don't already know about. I find it useful on occasion, but for general searches google is generally the best bet; just use a blank browser/incognito.

However, it seems that I'm literally the only shithead on Earth who is affected by this. Everyone else can still immediately find what they're looking for, even if it's buried on some obscure site or post that never shows up in any search results. When I spend 2 hours and come back with 1-2 things, everyone else can still find 731208560478534718232524 things per second. It's like they have some kind of telepathic ability to just pluck the links to what they want out of thin air.

One example is posting pictures. I created +foxes, and have trouble finding enough content because I can only search google images, reddit, and imgur. However, many posters could easily find multiple pics or videos from a variety of buried social media posts and extremely-little-known websites. They do this from tons of different sources, all the time.

Another example is news stories. Everyone except me can find about 100 cool news stories (or politicians' comments) per hour the nanosecond they come out, just by "looking" for them. Well I also look for them, and only ever find the very top, trending stories, that everyone has already seen. There is no way to find anything else other than pure luck, so I don't know what kind of magic you all are using.

So, search engines are basically useless now. So how does everyone still find everything online, and why does everyone always try to sidestep that question when I ask them (as if I'm not supposed to know for some reason)?
post.title: How do you all still find everything on the internet even though search engines suck now?

body:
Once you found a good site/blogs about a specific subject, It's very likely you will find all of the community behind it. I'm gonna give you an example.

[Here](defenseissues.net) is one blog talking mainly about military aviation. These guys are highly skilled and very knowledgeable on military shit. Know, very cool, but what do I do with this ? Start looking at the comments. You'll see that some of them have links towards other blogs. The potential amount of info is mind-blowing.

Finding the first site is always the most difficult. It's mostly a combination of smart keywords and advice by other anons.

parent.body: For news Google has ridiculous bias in which outlets it shows you. However, there's a trick to it: When running a normal search and hopping to the "News" tab, there are some options in the "Tools" menu that let you filter and sort stories by date rather than "relevance". All of a sudden you get to see smaller sites reporting on stories which the rest of the media refuse to cover, such as vote fraud at the moment. The normal algo will never show you it at all.

bro you're so fast at responding

what am I supposed to be looking at in the guilds you linked me? these people posting there are not everyone, and they may be actively looking at a site for news, kind of like how you would read the news paper every morning commuting to work in 1960 for what's new. and no one knows "literally every picture and video on the internet," people know sources. some of which may not show up *any more*, but used to. people know pictures and videos by chance, like how I know of a video of a praying mantis eating a woman's nipple by chance. it's not something I searched for (because I'm scarred) or really wanted to see, but I did. 

please just understand that it really is just a game of chance, this internet stuff. you're not always going to get something you're searching for. however you're not always *not* going to find something either.

post.body:
We all know that for a while, search engines (most famously Google) have started changing their algorithm to promote the content they want you to see, which makes it extremely hard to find what you're looking for. Even websites with their own search engines, like social media and news sites, are doing this.

However, it seems that I'm literally the only shithead on Earth who is affected by this. Everyone else can still immediately find what they're looking for, even if it's buried on some obscure site or post that never shows up in any search results. When I spend 2 hours and come back with 1-2 things, everyone else can still find 731208560478534718232524 things per second. It's like they have some kind of telepathic ability to just pluck the links to what they want out of thin air.

One example is posting pictures. I created +foxes, and have trouble finding enough content because I can only search google images, reddit, and imgur. However, many posters could easily find multiple pics or videos from a variety of buried social media posts and extremely-little-known websites. They do this from tons of different sources, all the time.

Another example is news stories. Everyone except me can find about 100 cool news stories (or politicians' comments) per hour the nanosecond they come out, just by "looking" for them. Well I also look for them, and only ever find the very top, trending stories, that everyone has already seen. There is no way to find anything else other than pure luck, so I don't know what kind of magic you all are using.

So, search engines are basically useless now. So how does everyone still find everything online, and why does everyone always try to sidestep that question when I ask them (as if I'm not supposed to know for some reason)?

parent.body: The thing about DDG is that it essentially ctrl+f's the search results and tries to give you something which contains as many of the words you typed as possible, without actually trying to make sense of the search inquiry the way google or other engines do. It does technically prevent censorship in that sense, but it also makes it very difficult to search for something you don't already know about. I find it useful on occasion, but for general searches google is generally the best bet; just use a blank browser/incognito.

parent.body: I've actually been using DDG as my main search engine for about a year, it does well even for more techincal things (which I had trouble with at the start of my use).  I was able to switch my parent's engine about 6 months ago with no complaints thus far.  I'd also have to use google for directions but since DDG started using apple maps, that is no longer the case.  I'm actually really satisfied with DDG.  I think one of the hardest things about switching is language.  "I'll google it" was a hard thing to recondition myself.

post.body:
We all know that for a while, search engines (most famously Google) have started changing their algorithm to promote the content they want you to see, which makes it extremely hard to find what you're looking for. Even websites with their own search engines, like social media and news sites, are doing this.

However, it seems that I'm literally the only shithead on Earth who is affected by this. Everyone else can still immediately find what they're looking for, even if it's buried on some obscure site or post that never shows up in any search results. When I spend 2 hours and come back with 1-2 things, everyone else can still find 731208560478534718232524 things per second. It's like they have some kind of telepathic ability to just pluck the links to what they want out of thin air.

One example is posting pictures. I created +foxes, and have trouble finding enough content because I can only search google images, reddit, and imgur. However, many posters could easily find multiple pics or videos from a variety of buried social media posts and extremely-little-known websites. They do this from tons of different sources, all the time.

Another example is news stories. Everyone except me can find about 100 cool news stories (or politicians' comments) per hour the nanosecond they come out, just by "looking" for them. Well I also look for them, and only ever find the very top, trending stories, that everyone has already seen. There is no way to find anything else other than pure luck, so I don't know what kind of magic you all are using.

So, search engines are basically useless now. So how does everyone still find everything online, and why does everyone always try to sidestep that question when I ask them (as if I'm not supposed to know for some reason)?

body:
that the thing though, you *think* it's the same all the time, when it's not. people telling you that they *always* get what they're searching for are lying, because for example, not everything is documented on the internet, or even researched. ie, eels, they're still a mystery to us, so if you search for how they reproduce, you're not going to get concrete evidence, links like you would for dogs. 

but again, people using browsers that are not actively censoring stuff or manipulating their algorithms like google or ddg, are more prone to get what they want; however they dont *always* get what they want.

parent.body: Ive been able to completely remove google from my vocabulary lol.  "Search it" or "Look it up" are easy enough to say
parent.body_html: Ive been able to completely remove google from my vocabulary lol. "Search it" or "Look it up" are easy enough to say

post.body:
We all know that for a while, search engines (most famously Google) have started changing their algorithm to promote the content they want you to see, which makes it extremely hard to find what you're looking for. Even websites with their own search engines, like social media and news sites, are doing this.

However, it seems that I'm literally the only shithead on Earth who is affected by this. Everyone else can still immediately find what they're looking for, even if it's buried on some obscure site or post that never shows up in any search results. When I spend 2 hours and come back with 1-2 things, everyone else can still find 731208560478534718232524 things per second. It's like they have some kind of telepathic ability to just pluck the links to what they want out of thin air.

One example is posting pictures. I created +foxes, and have trouble finding enough content because I can only search google images, reddit, and imgur. However, many posters could easily find multiple pics or videos from a variety of buried social media posts and extremely-little-known websites. They do this from tons of different sources, all the time.

Another example is news stories. Everyone except me can find about 100 cool news stories (or politicians' comments) per hour the nanosecond they come out, just by "looking" for them. Well I also look for them, and only ever find the very top, trending stories, that everyone has already seen. There is no way to find anything else other than pure luck, so I don't know what kind of magic you all are using.

So, search engines are basically useless now. So how does everyone still find everything online, and why does everyone always try to sidestep that question when I ask them (as if I'm not supposed to know for some reason)?

parent.body: I've actually been using DDG as my main search engine for about a year, it does well even for more techincal things (which I had trouble with at the start of my use).  I was able to switch my parent's engine about 6 months ago with no complaints thus far.  I'd also have to use google for directions but since DDG started using apple maps, that is no longer the case.  I'm actually really satisfied with DDG.  I think one of the hardest things about switching is language.  "I'll google it" was a hard thing to recondition myself.

It's like they have some kind of telepathic ability to just pluck the links to what they want out of thin air.

One example is posting pictures. I created +foxes, and have trouble finding enough content because I can only search google images, reddit, and imgur. However, many posters could easily find multiple pics or videos from a variety of buried social media posts and extremely-little-known websites. They do this from tons of different sources, all the time.

Another example is news stories. Everyone except me can find about 100 cool news stories (or politicians' comments) per hour the nanosecond they come out, just by "looking" for them. Well I also look for them, and only ever find the very top, trending stories, that everyone has already seen. There is no way to find anything else other than pure luck, so I don't know what kind of magic you all are using.

So, search engines are basically useless now. So how does everyone still find everything online, and why does everyone always try to sidestep that question when I ask them (as if I'm not supposed to know for some reason)?
post.title: How do you all still find everything on the internet even though search engines suck now?

body: I use Ecosia as my search engine and have never had any problems. Though when I use Google I definitely notice the slant and manipulation. DuckDuckGo tends to be good for searching somethings for me and not so good for others, I have hit or miss results with them, but for some searches I value privacy more than speedy accuracy. Learning to use the syntax helps a lot too in refining your searches.
